title: Asking the right questions
intro: What does it take to be a good interviewer? Neil and Alice discuss TV chat show hosts, Greek philosophers and whether asking dumb questions is a good idea or not – as well as teaching some related vocabulary.
this_week_question: Who developed a method of questioning around two and a half thousand years ago that aims to discover hidden truths? Was it…
You can hear the right answer at the end of the programme.

vocab.desc: to surprise someone in a way that often makes them confused or embarrassed
a TV or radio programme where celebrities talk to their host about various topics
a person who presents a TV or radio show and talks to guest celebrities
questions that can't be answered with a short answer for example a couple or words or yes or no; they often begin with 'wh' (why, what, who etc)
information you find interesting because it's exciting or shocking closed question a question where the choice of answers is limited for example to yes or no, or a specific piece of information
get or produce something, for example, a reaction
protecting yourself from criticism or attack

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: … and I'm Alice. Now Neil, I'm a big fan of chat shows, as you know. But what do you think makes a good interview?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I like it when the interviewer asks a question that catches the guest off guard . You know – to surprise them so they're embarrassed and don't know what to say.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: That's not very nice!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I know. But it's great TV. That's what chat shows are all about, isn't it?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, I don't agree, Neil! A chat show , by the way, is a TV or radio programme where a host – the person who presents the show – talks to guest celebrities about various topics. And what makes a good interview is the subject of today's show.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So what's a good interview technique, Alice?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, asking open questions – questions the celebrities can't easily respond to with a short answer. Open questions give them the chance to talk and possibly reveal some juicy details about themselves!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Juicy details means information you find interesting because it's exciting or shocking.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yes. So let's test your interviewing skills, Neil. Ask me something – see if you can get some juicy details.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK… Hmm… How much do you weigh?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: How much do I weigh?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: How much do you weigh? Look, that's a closed question – you're going to get a short answer and no juicy details! And more importantly, Neil, it's a rude question!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK – bad choice. Sorry. But your reaction was juicy – you got pretty hot under the collar – and that means embarrassed or angry! I'll try to think of a better question to ask you before the end of the show.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Alright then. Now, since you aren't good at asking questions, perhaps you can answer one instead. Who developed a method of questioning around two and a half thousand years ago that aims to discover hidden truths? Was it… a) Hippocrates? b) Socrates? Or c) Aristotle?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I don't know much about ancient history so I'm going to guess c) Aristotle.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out if you picked the right answer later on – but now let's listen to Larry King talking about the secret of his successful career as a TV chat show host. Can you spot a word that means to get or produce?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Larry King, TV chat show host, US If you ask good questions and you elicit thoughtful answers then you learn more about the person. If the interview's hard – if I begin by saying, 'Why did you do that?' I'd make you defensive. That may be thrilling television, but you don't learn a lot. I learned that the more I drew back, asked good questions, listened to the answers, cared about the guest … you make the camera disappear.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The word Larry King used is… elicit .

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Right. And you elicited a defensive reaction from me when you asked a not very thoughtful question about my weight. Defensive means protecting yourself from criticism or attack.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, I wouldn't make a good chat show host then.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: You're right there. So good interviewers draw back – or move away – from being the centre of attention. They're good listeners and care about their guests. Sound familiar?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Are you suggesting that you're a good interviewer?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Yup.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, well, so why aren't you a top chat show host, hmm? What does Larry mean when he says you have to make the camera disappear ?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: It means to make the conversation real – as if you were chatting with a friend – rather than performing to a TV audience. But let's hear more from Larry King on the secret of his success.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Larry King, TV chat show host, US I don't want a 'no'. I don't want a 'yes'. I want a 'why'. So in other words, I want to be a little kind of dumb. My friend Herbie said the secret of my success is being dumb. 'What do you mean by that?'

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So you have to ask dumb – or stupid – questions to make a great chat show host! I knew it!

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Maybe there's hope for you yet, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Charming.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Lovely. OK, here's the answer to today's quiz question. I asked: Who developed a method of questioning around two and a half thousand years ago that aims to discover hidden truths? Was it… a) Hippocrates? b) Socrates? Or c) Aristotle?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said c) Aristotle.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: No, it was b) Socrates. All three were famous Greek philosophers but Socrates was the one who angered lots of important people by his probing – or investigative – questions – and this technique is called Socratic Dialogue. Socrates lived from 469 to 399 BC and he influenced philosophy so much that all previous thinkers have come to be known as Pre-Socratic. Despite this he declared "All I know is that I know nothing".

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Very noble. OK, a final question for you, Alice. What makes you happy?

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Working with such a fantastic co-presenter, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's nice! I'm embarrassed now.

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Can you tell us the words we heard today?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Of course! catch somebody off guard chat show host open questions juicy details closed question hot under the collar elicit defensive draw back make the camera disappear dumb probing

transcript.author: Alice
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, do indeed!

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.
